Package imagingbook.lib.util

Class ResourceDirectory

  • java.lang.Object
    • imagingbook.lib.util.ResourceDirectory
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    Resources
    public abstract class ResourceDirectory
extends java.lang.Object
    Any resource directory is supposed to contain a class extending this class (the class name is arbitrary). This is to make sure that every resource directory is also a Java package known to exist at compile time. For example, in file imagingbook.data.images.DataDir.java: 
     package imagingbook.data.images;
 public class DataDir extends ResourceDirectory { }
    All resources are assumed to be local in the SAME directory ONLY, thereby avoiding the use of strings to specify sub-directories. Example how to access the associated resources from some other class: 
     ResourceDirectory rd = new imagingbook.data.images.DataDir();
 Path path = rd.getResourcePath("boats.tif");
    Specifically, an image can be opened as follows: 
     Path path = rd.getResourcePath("boats.tif");
 ImagePlus im = IjUtils.openImage(path);
 ImageProcessor ip = im.getProcessor();
 ...
    Version:
    2020/11/22

      • isInsideJAR

        public boolean isInsideJAR()
        Determines if this class was loaded from a JAR file or a .class file in the file system.
        Returns:
        true if contained in a JAR file, false otherwise

      • getResourcePath

        public java.nio.file.Path getResourcePath()
        Returns the path to the file location of this class.
        Returns:
        The path to this class.

      • getResourcePath

        public java.nio.file.Path getResourcePath​(java.lang.String resourceName)
        Returns the path to a resource relative to the location of this class.
        Parameters:
        resourceName - The resource's simple name (including file extension)
        Returns:
        The path to the specified resource or null if not found

      • getResourceNames

        public java.lang.String[] getResourceNames()
        Returns the simple names of all resources within this class's directory (excluding the class file itself). This should work in an ordinary file system as well as a (possibly nested) JAR file.
        Returns:
        A sorted array of names (possibly empty)
